displayed_text: Healthcare Professional: If they’re available. Patient: I don’t think there’s really any hard dates that we need to have or need to work around- Family Member: I can’t think of any. Patient: in the next month or two. Well, you’ll scheduled to be the driver. Family Member: No. Oh, no it won’t. I mean they told multiple times they’ll work with me and so that is not lip service. Patient: Larry said he’d be willing to, as long as, he’s thinking, two to three hours. Or if he can get me here, somebody will get me out. Healthcare Professional: Uh, yes. CALLER Good afternoon, Infusion, this is M_. Doctor: M_ in charge? CALLER Yes. Family Member: Umm, will the, will the chemo class help me understand what my, what I need to do to protect him from whatever I’m supposed to protect him from? Doctor: Uh, yes, I mean, they will allow you to ask questions about anything you should be worried about, things you’ve heard, and you can go from there as to sort of whether should you worry or not worry. Umm. And so these are people that have been through it with a lot of people, so they should be able to guide you about what, you know, what’s real worry and what’s not real worry. Family Member: So, we’re normally the household that people come to for Christmas, probably twenty five people. Depending on where we are in the scheme of things, do I want that many people around? Doctor: Uh, right. So, when you pick your date for chemo with T_,

Patient: It’s organic medicine. Doctor: Right. You know, we’ve done studies with pomegranates and muscadine grapes, and it sort of extends to that sort of area. Uh, but this again is, uh, experimental. Patient: Right. Doctor: Um. So, in that study, we’re looking at how you tolerate it. Uh, what’s the safe dose. Ah, and then, you know, we monitor your disease; that if it’s not getting better, then we move on. If it is improving or not - stable, you can stay with that treatment. Patient: Okay. Family Member: It’s a phase one. How long does the phase one run for? Uh, because I’m wondering if there are subsequent phases, um but Doctor: So, typically, we treat three men at a one-dose level. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: And, if they all do well and nothing happens to them, then we treat three more men at a higher dose level, and if nothing happens to them, we go to a higher dose level. Um. Patient: With different people? Doctor: Different people. You know? I would have to check. Again, some of the things we’d have to clarify. Uh, it is – if you’re, let’s say you’re --come in at the second dose level, and you are on it and it, it’s not, the cancer’s not getting worse. Uh, does it make sense to go to the higher dose. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: That those men are safe. Or, the fact that your cancer’s not getting worse, why would we change the dose?

Patient: Yes. Doctor: It sounds like we’re going to keep you on the study for now. In order to do so, we have to stop the medication to allow this anemia to recover. Hopefully, it will. Uh, so as of today, uh, no more Patient: Okay. Doctor: Until you come back and see us on September the fifth. Uh, L___ will be in touch with you after she comes back. Family Member: She’ll be here tomorrow. Doctor: She actually had to leave unexpectedly because her house had some flooding which she had to take care of, which is why she’s not here. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But, uh, we will schedule the, uh, complete blood count which includes hemoglobin for next Monday, Tuesday, or Wednesday, the early part of next week. Based on that, I will make a decision about whether a transfusion will be necessary or not. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: If the transfusion is necessary, we’ll also do that through the K___ system. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And we will have all that completed before September fifth. So that when you come back, we’ll give you the best possible chance to start the medication again, albeit at a lower dose, because it’ll be the two-hundred milligram dose.

Patient: Probably a program. Doctor: ‘Cuz we would put the prescription into our pharmacy. We would have them figure out how much it’s gonna cost you, and then if it’s too much, they could start looking for these plans that they cover the cost for you. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And if that’s so, then it would be cheap. Then you would be taking a drug that I don’t think is gonna work with the idea that I need you to be on this drug so that the immune therapy might work which is research, experimental, unsure. Okay? Family Member: Is there any way on the portal – his daughter wants to keep up what’s, what’s going over -- like what we said today. Does she have your power of something? Have some way that she can check on, uh – like MyLGHHealth, I can go in there and see, read everything, and results and that. Doctor: Yeah, I mean, he is active on MyChart. That’s where I wrote you that note. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So he can let her – Family Member: Okay. Doctor: He can give her the password. The system doesn’t know who’s looking. You know, but it is his password. Family Member: Right. Okay. Doctor: Okay? But you need to be able to call her or talk to her or you have to sign forms out front to give me release. Okay?

Family Member 1: And she does yoga. Doctor: I’m very relaxed in here. Oh my gosh. (laughing) Family Member 1: She teaches yoga too Doctor. Doctor: Are you okay? Patient: Yeah, I'm fine. I’m just concerned about that PSA going up. Doctor: Yeah so we gotta start. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So again, we kind of ran through the gamut, you know, you need some sort of chemo. So, you know, we talked last time the chemo was just ready to go, just chemo chemo. Then we have the chemo that's a trial with regular chemo versus a pill version. Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: Now, that's not the first time we've done a pill version. It's the first time we've done it for this chemo. But like, there's an all time chemotherapy called FIVFU, that they made a pill version of that called Xeloda. So that's an active practice if you have like colon cancer, it's just not something we routinely use for prostate, but the idea has been around so it's not super novel, but we've never done it for this type of chemotherapy. So if it works, it's Patient: So is this what you want to put me on? Doctor: Yes, because the other one and just for timing wise, the other one is also fine with chemo, but the vitamin C, that's high dose. So again, natural but still high doses requires IV. You're here twice a week, every week sort of indefinitely. So it's a big time sink. So I kind of wanted to at least offer you the less intensive one, but also So I think very effective. Patient: Okay.

Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: So, there’s a, there’s a couple of trials that are in the works that might be specifically suited for you Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because of this mutation. Patient: So, we’re not, not doing standard of care. Doctor: Right. Patient: Pat We’re looking at potent—very, uh, plausibly potential choices down the road. Doctor: Yes. Patient: And, and, and so at this point --- Doctor: I mean, including standard of care. So, standard of care is always our baseline. Patient: Right. Doctor: And then we, you know, I could just, my description will be, “here’s what standard of care does, here’s what we expect.”

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.4 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::4 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.disagree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::disagree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.strongly agree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::strongly agree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.disagree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::disagree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.neutral: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::neutral

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Disabled: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Disabled

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White
What race or races do you consider yours.American Indian or Alaska Native: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::American Indian or Alaska Native

displayed_text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: So I think he’s mentioned in his note a standard option for you go to would be to chemotherapy. So chemotherapy in someone like you after hormones haven’t worked well enough or long enough; Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: chemotherapy shrinks the PSA for a while, shrinks the tumor for a while in about forty/fifty percent of people. So almost half the people get some benefit from chemotherapy. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: We usually know after three or four cycles as to whether or not it’s gonna help, and we keep going. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: We also sort of know what side effects you’re going to experience to sort of see whether you can tolerate this. We have to adjust the doses about that. So that’s an approved drug that’s known to extend survival if people get the drugs, tolerate the drugs, respond to the drugs. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: You know those people can do well compared to those who don’t respond or don’t get the drug. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So chemo would be something that you know it could be given here, it could be given there, but it’s standard treatment.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: But your insurance today is not playing nice and it’s not letting us treat you today. Family Member: What? Doctor: Uh huh. Yes. K__’s yelling at somebody on the phone. United Health Care is not being very nice to you right now. And you know we put this in I don’t know how long ago right since the last time I’d seen you. They have hemmed and hawed and hemmed and hawed and given all sorts of problems. Patient: What do I need to do? Doctor: I don’t know. Patient: Can I do anything. I mean… Doctor: Yeah I mean I think if we don’t get an answer today we’re gonna have to shoot somebody there. Doctor: That’s on video too. Yeah. Patient: We got this. Doctor: Yeah… Patient: Is there anything… Doctor: Well the good news is – no – I mean the good news is you know whether you get it today or next week, it doesn’t matter. You’ll still do well.

Healthcare Professional: Um hum. Doctor: - depending on. And then um in point six percent of people you could get a seizure. I point that out out of all the list because that’s to me the most scary - Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: - if it were me. But you know point six is less – Family Member: Right. Doctor: - than one as in we give this stuff all the time and people, knock on wood - Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: - have not had it as an issue. Family Member: Everybody has their issues. Doctor: It is. So every time you read that consent form it’s like you opened up a bottle of Motrin, took out the little package insert, (HCP laughing) Family Member: You know even one person Doctor: Um hum. FAM - who’s on the study said oh I had seizures – Healthcare Professional: You have to write it down.

Patient: So when I get it on the eighth in terms of my work schedule; I’m an attorney; if I have a trial like the ninth or the tenth, can I - Doctor: Sure, you’ll be fine. Patient: Okay. Doctor: You’ll be fine. Patient: Got-cha. No problem, thank you. Doctor: You’re welcome. Uhm, so if you’re going to do the eighth and I’m going to see you, D____ needs to talk to you about some medicine you’re going to take beforehand. Patient: Okay. Doctor: That keeps you from having the side effects. And she’ll give you a prescription. That’s the only other thing we’ll give you. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Unless you think of anything else. Patient: The testosterone and the shot. Thank you very much. Have a good week. Doctor: All right. I’ll be waiting. Healthcare Professional: The effects of

Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So here are the orders themselves. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Again, this should have been submitted to LabCorp. But if you don’t have them, instead of calling over and having to get it faxed, you can hold onto that. Patient: Okay, doctor. Thank you, sir. Doctor: I will see you both in January. Patient: In January and then Doctor: The date we picked, it was the seventeenth. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: The timing, the timing and the schedule . Okay, so have a nice holiday season. Patient: Okay, you, too. Have a safe trip. Thank you. Doctor: Nice to see both of you.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: It may potentially lessen the side effects if you do it that way without the Lupron at the same time. Patient: Yeah, yeah. For some reason the Lupron, that just knocks me out. For some reason I forget a lot of things, hallucination; I get a Doctor: Great, now when would you like to check the next PSA level and when would you like to do it? Patient: Now next PSA, now did you place an order for mine? Doctor: I did. Patient: Okay, because when I went there they said they didn’t see it. Doctor: Okay. Patient: And I had to call in and they faxed it. Doctor: Okay. I will do two things today. When I place the prescription I will send electronically and then I will also print the actual paper prescription. Patient: Okay. Uh huh. Doctor: And hand it to you. That should be the backup.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: -and then you get randomized to the muscadine grape skin or placebo. And if you are on the placebo arm, if your PSA, if it's if the placebo is not working, then you get the muscadine grapeseed. Okay, so, eventually everybody on the trial can get the therapy. Okay? If you're not this genotype and you're not eligible because we don't think that you'll, you'd have any benefit. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But to see if you would be eligible for the study, you'd have to first join the study, then we do this genotype testing. And then if you're eligible, about 25% of the population is eligible. So you have a one in four shot. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then if you're eligible, I think that that would actually be a reasonable option. Okay. The other trial is a trial of alaparib. This study is, a study of, it, so it's a PARP inhibitor. This medicine is used in breast cancer and ovarian cancer, and it's used sometimes in advanced prostate cancer, and we're studying to see if it can be used early on without hormone therapy in prostate cancer. Just to spare people from prostate cancer. The MAP study, the muscadine grape skin has very few side effects gas, upset stomach, this one can cause nausea and vomiting and can sometimes cause your blood counts to go lower. This is like an expensive medicine that is provided but usually you have to go through insurance for all the clinical trials. So this and this one, I'm not positive that you're eligible for yet either. Okay. So those are the two clinical trial options that we have for biochemical recurrence. Family Member: How soon can he get into the trial? Doctor: So what usually happens in general for clinical trials is that if you're interested in clinical trials, what I'll do is I'll contact the research nurse, and I'll say, you know, “Mr. H____ is interested in this clinical trial let's do it” because we have to make sure that your insurance allows you to be in clinical trials, and we have to confirm your eligibility and like for this, the MAP study- Family Member: Mhm. Doctor: -we would have you sign consent to do the testing to see the genotype first. So usually the time, from like, we're talking about it, and you are thinking about doing it to like, actually starting is a couple weeks. Family Member: Two to four. Doctor: It's always like, yeah, like, almost always within a month.

Patient: No I ain’t saw you either. (Laughs) Doctor: W____ will come in with the paperwork and then we’ll get you out of here. Patient: Okay fine. Doctor: Okay? Any questions? Patient: No. Doctor: No? Patient: No not really. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Not at this point anyway. Doctor: Awesome. Happy New Year to both of you. Family Member: Thank you. Doctor: Nice to see you, nice to see you.

Patient: How are you today? Doctor: Good timing. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I thought otherwise usually when I walk in you’re not here or something. Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: That’s how it works out. Okay how are you feeling? How are the joints and everything else? Patient: Yeah, it’s all – it’s all good. Doctor: That’s all okay? Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: That has not acted up or gotten worse in the last few… Patient: No, no. Not since I went back on the prednisone. Doctor: Okay. Patient: I’ve been fine since then.
